segments.text: Hello and welcome to the Slate Political Gaffes for April 23rd, 2020, the Georgia Out
of Its Mind edition.
I am David Plots in Closet in Washington, DC, joining me from her home in New Haven, Connecticut,
Emily Bazzlon of the New York Times Magazine.
Hello, Emily.
Hello.
The garbage truck is pulling up outside my house at this very second, so if you hear it,
that's why.
Essential services being conducted by the good public servants of New Haven, I'm glad
to hear it.
And joining from a tent, a tent perhaps in his home is John Dickerson of CBS's 60 Minutes.
Hello, John.
Hello, David.
Yes, it reminds me, sorry, the curtains pulled over me because I'm recording my audiobook
in this little corner of the room where I've got the curtains basically attached to both
walls.
And it reminds me when I was a little kid, I used to make sheet forts and so I'm feeling
I'm feeling about seven years old.
Did you used to record radio shows in your sheet forts back in the day?
Your mom was a broadcast journalist after all.
You know, I didn't, but I used to put a fan at the end of the sheet forts so the sheets
would fill up with air.
And now I fill this tent for it up with my own hot air.
Did you guys find that the world seemed a little gloomier, that people seem a little
gloomier this week?
It felt, for some reason, whatever adrenaline I think that was carrying people through the
first month, even people who are in pretty good shape and who don't have sick ones and

It's not been a great feeling this week.
I think it goes up and down.
I haven't noticed a linear, any linear direction of anything.
I feel like it's more sort of minor yoyoing.
A secondary spike, as it were.
Yeah.
I've been wondering what the benefit or detriment of actually keeping a watch on the fibrillations
of the psychological and emotional barometer are.
Because every time I do, then I spiral into thinking about, well, is this the right level
of doom thinking?
And shouldn't I be constantly thinking about the doom of the sorrow and the total chaos
and upset in the world?
So I'm taking a constant reading of the rest of the world has been something that has its
own perils.
I totally agree.
I think it would be better to be less informed right now that actually if you could just
say, wake me up when this is over or wake me up when something actually happens that matters,
but it's impossible because it feels like anything could matter.
So we should stop the recording.
Right.
Everybody stop listening.
I think...
Quick show.
Thanks for listening.
Right.
I mean, also because it's our job to stare right at the doom.
And I don't mean the physical, actually, a lot of it.
I mean, the economic and the cultural and all that.
For me, I think it's maybe that I had this realization this week that all the kind of,
oh, this could be better than this could be optimistic.
Here's a thing that could happen faster.
Here's a way it couldn't go as badly as it could.
All of those things have not come to pass.
Basically everything.
We're in a kind of a worst case scenario.
Not in terms of death.
Not in terms of death.
That is true.
That it doesn't seem that as many people will perish from this directly as maybe expected.
But certainly everything else in terms of when life can return to life, it seems to be on
the slow timeline, not the fast.
And maybe that's what's gotten me depressed.
Well, I think...
Have we even introduced the topic?
No, we haven't introduced the topics yet.
Sorry.
I'll say one more thing.
This is important conversation.
Okay.
I think this is our first topic, basically.
But I think part of what's happening is because the conversation about when and how to reopen
parts of the country has so polarized as just like a common sense matter, it's hard to
figure out what those steps are.
Yeah.
Well, right, which makes it hard because we're all looking for a solution and something in
the drawer that will help us at least begin opening this complicated can.
And everything in the drawer looks totally insufficient to the task, which is itself
an existential irritant because I've been thinking a lot about hope, real hope, real
durable hope, right?
Not just pain, glossion, foolishness, or the motivational poster you pass on your way to
the break room.
But what makes durable hope is people who even in the face of overwhelming uncertainty and

So where do you find that?
Who has it?
And it takes its first kernels in good, like solid solutions and information that begins

And it's when you're going out looking for that tiny little kernel and you keep finding
full gold, it can be frustrating.
But of course, that's always what happens.
So you have to keep going on.
But I totally agree with what you're saying, Emily.
All right.
On today's Gavfest, we're going to talk about the culture war over reopening the country,
over immigration, over COVID testing.
Then are women better suited to lead during this pandemic than men?
And then we'll talk to Mark Bitman, his new book is How to Eat.
He's going to come talk about the politics and philosophy of food in a time of pandemic.
Plus, of course, we will have cocktail chatter.
So here's a question that came up this week.
Are we in the middle of a COVID-19 culture war, one that could have real consequences
for health and the economy?
The president has taken the opportunity of the pandemic to massively restrict immigration.
He did that this week.
The question of reopening has taken on a partisan cast.
We have Trump leading governors pushing hardest for early openings, in particular with the
governor of Georgia, who pushed to open this week.
He's going to allow certain kinds of businesses to operate that are not allowed to operate
in other places, although the president then quickly criticized him for doing it.
So John, let's start with this question of reopening.
Why is the debate over reopening so heated?
We have protests.
We have governors in Georgia and South Carolina and Florida pushing for fast movement on it.
We have Bill Barr threatening to take action against states that restrict the movement
of their citizens too much.
Why is it a become an issue of liberty, not an issue of public health?
Well, one of the problems is we don't really know how much of it is really an issue.
The Associated Press had a poll out on Wednesday night and it said that only 12% of the country
thinks the measures have gone too far.
So only 12% of the country is in support of the people who've been protesting in these
various states, Michigan, Ohio, Colorado.
And wasn't it only 22% of Republicans?
I saw your tweet.
Sorry.
And even more fascinating to me is that with a president who has 90% approval rating in
his own party, which is very durable as we've seen, that inside that eight people, only
22% of Republicans think that the measures have gone too far.
So that's among Republicans.
So one of the things we're trying to get a handle on is how much do people feel, ah,
this is a little, I mean, overwhelming polls show consistently, massively and constantly
that the, that the country is very much behind the measures that have been taken so far.
And they're more worried about opening up too soon than the alternative.
It's just the polling is consistent on that.
So where does this come from?
Some of it's manufactured.
Some of it is that 40% that we talked about many issues ago or many episodes ago of the
chaos voter, the chaos person, the person who just enjoys stirring the pot.
And then I think it's also negative partisanship, which is that the people who are advocating
for staying in and for all of these strict measures tend to be from blue states, sort
of nanny state virtue signaling types.
So even if I might in theory think it's good as a matter of public health, I don't like
the people who are telling me this.
And so I want to kick them in the teeth.
And there's a lot of genuine frustration and suffering of people who didn't have a whole
bunch of money in their bank account.
And now we're into their sixth week of not making any money and they need something to
change and they're sharing a kind of frustration we started the show with, which is everywhere
I look for a solution of how to get out of this.
I'm not getting good information.
I'm getting more confused.
I would just add to that.
There's a rural urban divide going on, right?
There are parts of the country where the virus, I think, does not feel present.
I mean, in my small city, it feels among us like I know people in New Haven have it.
And I know a lot of people work at the hospital, so I hear about it.
But I can imagine being somewhere more remote where this just still feels like someone else's
problem.
Or even if you sympathize on a human level, you think, well, wait a second, but why can't
I buy grass seed at the store?
Like how is my not being able to go to that store in my town really going to help anyone?
Right.
I want to add to that, which is, I mean, I think the governor of Georgia is proposing
to do is coming too soon.
It's too that that state is not ready, but it's really important to always remember
that the economic costs are health costs.
We have higher stress.
Our children are not getting educated.
We have high unemployment.
All of those are going to contribute to worse health outcomes for people and unhappiness
in the future.
It is absolutely the case.
I think the cost benefit analysis is what we have to endure that.
We have to accept that because the immediate catastrophic outcome of allowing this thing
to rampage is too great.
And we would have the same thing anyway.
We would still have the same amount of economic destruction anyway.
But I think there's a failure.
It has not been well explained to the public why the suffering is required now, why the
suffering is required and why you would have it anyway, whether you let the disease rampage
or you don't let the disease rampage.
That explanation feels like it's been inadequately done.
I totally agree.
I totally agree.
This is one place where a good leader and it's what FDR did with explaining to people,
I totally see you.
I mean, there's one group of people who are going through the grief of loss or the grief
of not being able to visit a loved one who's on a ventilator.
And seeing that grief is important.
But seeing what you described and that we've talked about before and you guys reacted to
immediately, I feel in the first show we did on this, which is the overwhelming kind of
terminal illness feeling of economic uncertainty.
You can't plan for the future.
I mean, all of your normal rhythms of life that come from economic disruption and seeing
that and understanding it and speaking it back to your citizens as a governor or as a president,
really in a way that lets them feel seen is a key job of leadership that isn't being
done.
And then pivoting and saying, even though I see you in your suffering, the reason we
have to do this as painful as it is is because we don't want to jumpstart our economy on
the backs of a boom in mortuaries or a boom in casket sales.
An economy cannot quote unquote open if people are dying in massive numbers and the hospitals
are overloaded.
The failure is not been just to not explain it well, but to set up a framing of it in
which the idea is that the economy can quote unquote open again when nobody has walked
through exactly what that will look like, the economy is not going to open if people
are nervous about going out again.
And they are constantly nervous and it's the job of leaders to make them feel more confident,
which goes back to your original point in how poorly people have or a lot of leaders
have made the case that you're making about why this is necessary and why there's hope
in a future plan if we stick to what we're doing now.
Right.
I mean, I also feel like John, all of the sense of shared sacrifice and purpose that
you're conveying, but that President Trump is not conveying.
If I had faith in that and especially if I had faith that everyone was in this together
across racial divides, across where you live, right?
Because one of the things that's really worrisome to me is you see the much higher disproportionate
death rates among African Americans in particular.
And then I worry at least about these comments from people who live not in the city part
of their states about like, well, if you could just like wall off Pittsburgh and Philadelphia
are just wall off Chicago, like that's the opposite of what we're striving for.
But Trump plays into all of that.
And then of course he brought in all this anti-immigrant xenophobia this week, like right on cue.
If we had that, I think it would be easier to get the short term total shutdown that
the public health folks pretty unanimously said we needed.
And then you can have a more common sensical, less political conversation about what makes
sense to open and what makes sense to keep closed.
And there are specific choices about that that like are worth talking about, right?
I mean, to open gyms and nail salons in Georgia seems crazy to me.
I don't understand that.
And it'll be really interesting to see who shows up at those gyms.
But you know, the feed store in some rural part of Michigan, like maybe that's a different

only a few people allowed into the store at once.
That seems like something maybe you could imagine happening.
What is it going to take to bridge that gap, to get there to be a more universal sense

public health measures will have to remain?
Is it even possible for us to have enough consensus as a society these days or is the

And without consensus, you can't have the collective action that's required to limit
this.
And therefore, we're just going to be in this state of misery for months and months and
months because we never get a handle on it.
Well, I think one of the possible roots to that, and we'll talk about this more in our
second topic on leadership, but is the governors.
It's amazing to see the way in which individual governors that have taken command of the moment,
even those who may have been sluggish at first or may not get a plus grades from preparation
or whatever, have been able to command the public space following pretty much the basic
rules of leadership, taking responsibility, being dedicated to clean and clear information,
showing the kind of empathy we were talking about earlier.
I mean, these governors in Ohio, New York, California are getting approval ratings at
levels we thought maybe no politician could get in this current age.
So if they use the structure they build in this current moment to say, to then give clear

So for example, the standard appears to be that if 10% of your cases come back positive,
you're doing sort of okay in terms of moving into this next phase.
Because if you're doing a high enough level of testing, that's what you're doing.
Well, no, no.
Well, what it means, as I understand it, is if it's at 10% or below in terms of confirmation,
no matter how much testing you're doing, then you're probably not missing a bunch of stuff
that's out there in the rest of the population.
If it's higher than 10%, and Georgia is 23%, though there's some quibbling about whether

more recently.
But if there's 23% or over 10%, it means there's a lot out there that you're not capturing
because you're not testing enough because we don't have enough tests.
So in a limited testing environment where you can't test everybody, you want your number
to be at 10% or lower.
So if you explain to people, hey, we're at 10%.
So South Carolina is 11, Florida is at 10, Ohio is at 14.
You say, here's the number.
Here's why we feel confident that we can take these baby steps.
That's our first metric, and we're going to keep focused on that.
And then the next metric is testing, and here are our metrics on that.
And then our next metric after that is our ability to contact trace and to isolate once

And here's how you can judge us on whether we're doing a good job there.
If you lay out those metrics and then have briefings of the kind that Cuomo's been doing

We said it was 10%.
Now we're at 12.
So I'm a little nervous.
We may not go into phase three as soon as we had hoped.
Then at least you're giving people the confidence A, of clean information and B, some standard
that isn't constantly moving.
And the governor's seem to be the only voices.
I mean, the federal response and the federal voices are a mess.
And are a mess in real time.
It doesn't have to do with what they missed, you know, back in January, what they missed
in February, what they missed in March.
The number of switchbacks and confusing signals and wasted time at the federal level means
I think it's just impossible to get clean information from the federal level.
So David, your route has to, it seems to me, come through the governors.
Yeah, it's really interesting from a federalism point of view.
I wrote a piece weeks ago saying like, hey, the governors can't solve this problem by

They can raise hell about the failures of the federal government, but they still need
help.

And they could really use national coordination on testing and tracing on these kind of next

I think it's really interesting to see these compacts and there is a way in which some

The other thing I really like about the benchmarks you just laid out is that they get us away

And so we need other kinds of benchmarks that allow us to make peace with the fact that some

And I feel like that's the, that's what we're groping toward in terms of figuring out what

So one thing I will, I will give the governors in the south is I think that opening the beaches

If that turns out to be true and it looks like, you know, for example, there wasn't a

Opening outdoor space opening parks may turn out to be some real relief that that people

And just to be clear, even on the beaches, you have to social distance.
I just want to make that.
But I just want to emphasize another point here, which is yes, federalism is this mixed

This is a case where federalism is a blessing, which is that actually we don't know very
much about the virus.
We don't know very much about transmission.
We don't know very much about what steps are going to take to open and reopen.
And I don't think it's a terrible thing to have different states moving at different
rates and trying different things.
I think that's okay.
I think it's a way, it's a way of discovery.
It's not as though the public health people, what they were telling us in February was

We don't.
We're learning.
And so the idea that you're like, okay, open the beaches.
Let's try it.
Let's see what happens.
Let's allow water skiing in Michigan.
Let's be a little bit creative and a little bit open to the idea that we're going to learn

And we don't really know how that changes our risk profile.
And that seems welcome.
And I do not like, I think, you know, in general, the left, such, you know, the left
and right debate over here that the left has been smarter about COVID and more cautious
and that has generally been smarter.
But I do think that the slamming of people walking in the beaches in Florida as idiots

I think it's allowing there needs to be a kind of variety in how we respond to it because
we actually don't know enough yet to say we absolutely have to do this.
We can't allow people to do this, this, and this.
We just don't know.
Yeah, that I agree.
I think one of the other irritating things if we could banish the irritating things,
which is my constant joy in life, is then also being clear about the limits of federalism.
It has all of the good things you say and is right into its experimental function.
Although, boy, if I'm experimenting, I would like my governor but not to be the one who

And by the way, the finding is on asymptomatic spread, which we've known about for a long

That doesn't help if they're asymptomatic yet they're still spreading.
But I would prefer to have the governor who was on top of the facts from the beginning,

All of those areas where the federal government could have done something and can do something,

but I think it is one of the other things to keep top of mind because the political
conversation seeks to fuzzy all this up.

It is striking how many of the most effective leaders of this crisis have been women just
into Ardern.

Ardern.
I'm going to say Ardern in New Zealand has been one of the most effective at quashing the

Yes, don't get a sensualist.
I don't want to get a sensualist.

Well, but everybody thinks you're going to.
Emily, jump in.
I should note, by the way, John Dickerson now sounds different.

Emily, let's get to it.
Is there anything that one can say that defines a female leadership style that makes it relevant

Is there a female leadership style that any of these women represent that is important
to note, or is it different from a male leadership style, or is this just a person
by person thing?
I have some theories, but I think there's some evidence that women when they're at the

At a moment like this, where there's so much uncertainty and you have to be taking in a

That country is going to send its kids back to school in May.

Why as a Jewish person?
Did you say that?
Because of the Nazis, remember that?
I know, but it's that's like 80 years ago.
It's a totally different country.
What a weird thing to say.
That's so interesting.

Oh, so on the one hand, in some of the writing about this, you have the male leadership style

Men could do them better, just aren't as many examples of them.
And then there are though that those natural things that Emily, you put your finger on,

In other words, Eisenhower said you don't lead by hitting people over the head.
That's assault, not leadership.
If you ascribe to the view that I think is right that women leaders tend to be more consensus

And then you have this other thing, which is in America, the kind of John Wayne version

The stock market, which is seen as a way to measure the success of a presidential leader

And then you have a president right now who keeps referring to his ratings, which are

The polls would suggest that he's not, that he's actually doing worse as a leader than

the things that are being ascribed to women leaders and that represent that more general
kind of successful leadership playbook.
All right.
I have so many thoughts on this.
First of all, I totally agree with your guys' point about the consensus building.
I think to be a woman who's successful in politics in almost any country, you have to
be calm and you have to be a consensus builder and you also have you.
It's very unsafe to show anger and to show too much kind of warlike or belligerent

And so this is a time when I think people are appreciating a calmness, a reasonableness

One part of what we're describing as female leadership is just like humanity, which is

are displaying empathy and that it is not that women display empathy or men display
empathy.
It's like anyone can display empathy.
It just happens that the women who are leading these countries are displaying empathy and

And I actually think what we have is not a, we don't have a kind of blossoming of great

I think what we have is a particularly terrible crop of male leaders.
I also want to say that all of the countries that we've talked about in New Zealand, this

And that's one reason why women are able to get elected.
Women tend not to get elected in countries that don't have such sort of political systems.
And so I think these women certainly are displaying excellent leadership, but they

Now I want to make the main point I want to make, which is I do not think, as I said,
I don't think that this is an incredible crop of women leaders, although, you know, Angela
Merkel, good, great work.
I think we have a huge amount of macho bluster horror show in the male leadership globally
these days.
I think about Trump, Boris Johnson, Bolsonaro in Brazil, Amlo in Mexico, Erdogan, Putin,
MBS, Modi in India, Xi Jinping, the kind of maleocracy of Iran.
It is a bunch there because of other forces that have been going on in global politics.
We have elected or not elected in some cases seized power across the world, men who are
particularly at this moment, populist macho bluster rain, and they are just doing very
